div.l: And at the mylle yet toke they ther cake
Of half busshel flour͗e weel y make
Thus is the proude Miller weel y bete
And hath y loste the gryndyng of his whete
And payed for the soper eủery deel
Of Aleyn̄ an of Iohn þat bete hym weel
His wyfe is swyfed and his douter als
Lo suche it is a Miller for to be fals
And therfore this ꝓproủerbe is seid full sooth
Hym thar nat wene weel þat euel dooth
A guylour shall hym self aguyled be
And god þat sitteth hygh in maieste
Save al this companye grete and smale
Thus haue I quytte the myller in his tale

Here begynneth the prolog͗e of the
Cokes Tale
The cook of london̄ while þe Reue spake
For ioye he thought he glowed on þe bak
Ha ha qᵈuod he for crystes passioıı̄un
This myller hath a sharpe conclusioun
Vp on his argument of harbergage
Weel seyde Salamon̄ in his langage
Ne bryng nat eủery man in to thyne hous
For herboryng by nyght is perelous
Weel aught a man avysed for to be
Whom þat he brought into his preuyte
Y pᵃray to god so geve me sorwe and care
If eủere sithen I hight hodge of ware
Herde I any Miller better sette on werke
He hadde a Iape of malice in the derk

A tale of me þat am a pore man̄
I wole yow telle as weel as eủere I can
A litel Iape that fill in oure Cite
Our͗e ooste answered and seid I graunte the
Now telle on Roger loke that it be good
For many a paste haue thow leten̄ blood
And many a Iakke hast thow solde
That hath be twyes hote and twyes colde
Of many a pilgryme hast thow cristes curse
For of thy parcely yet fare they the werse
That they haue eten̄ yet wᵗith þine stuble goos
For in thy shoppe is many a flee loos
Now telle on gentel Roger be thy name
But yet I pray the be nathnathnat wrooth for game
A man may say full soth in game and pleye
Thow saist full true qᵈuod Roger by my feye
But soth pleye quade pleye as þe flēmmyng seith
And therfor herry baylyf by my feyth
Be thow nat wrooth er we departen̄ here
Though þat my tale be of an Ostelere
But n̉erthelesse I wole nat telle it yet
But er we parte I wis thow shal be quytte
And ther with all lough and made good cheer͗e
And seid his tale as ye shal after here
Here endeth the prolog͗e and now

l.hi: begynneth the Tale of the Coke

div.l: A Prentys whilom duelled in oure Cite
And of a crafte of vitailers was he
Gailard he was as goldfynch in the shawe
Broune as a bery a ꝓpropre short felowe
With lokkes y kembed full fetisly
Daunce he coude so weel and iolely
That he was cleped parkyn Reveloᵘur
He was full of love and ꝑparamoᵘur
As is the hyve full of hony swete
Weel was the wenche with hym myght mete
At eủery bryde ale wold he syng and hoppe
He loued better þe taủerne thanne the shoppe
For whan ther͗e any ridyng were in chepe
Out of the shoppe theder wolde he lepe
Till þat he had all the sight y seyne
And daunced weel wold he nat come a geyne
And gadered hym a meny of his sorte
To hoppe and syng and make desporte
And there they setten̄ steuene for to mete
To pleyen̄ at þe dyce in suche a strete
For in the toun̄ ne was ther non app̉rentice
That fayre coude cast a peyre of dyes
Thanne ꝑperkyn coude and þerto he was free
Of his dispence in place of preuyte
That fonde his maister weel in his chafare
For often tyme he fond his box full bare
For sikerly a prentys Reuelour
That haunteth Ryot dyce or ꝑparamour͗e
His maister schuld in his shoppe a bye
All have he nat parte of his mynystralsye
